trans-unit.source: A very simple dialogue to request a password. - The dialog is displayed with a menu bar - The text box uses the font "%password" to hide the input. - The buttons are arranged according to their labels and may be inverted depending on the OS. - The validation button is only activated if a password is entered - Validation is only accepted if the password is correct (does not accept "1234" for the example)
trans-unit.target: A very simple dialogue to request a password. - The dialog is displayed with a menu bar - The text box uses the font "%password" to hide the input. - The buttons are arranged according to their labels and may be inverted depending on the OS. - The validation button is only activated if a password is entered - Validation is only accepted if the password is correct (does not accept "1234" for the example)

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to use the menuBar and menu classes to - Define, install and manage a menu bar - Define, display and manage generic menus provided by the class (Fonts, Windows) - Define, display and manage contextual menus to suit your needs
trans-unit.target: This example shows how to use the menuBar and menu classes to - Define, install and manage a menu bar - Define, display and manage generic menus provided by the class (Fonts, Windows) - Define, display and manage contextual menus to suit your needs

trans-unit.source:
You're familiar with the move and resize properties offered by the form editor for objects: Do nothing, move OR resize. Is that enough for you? Not for me. This dialog shows you how to use the "constraints" property of the "form" class to better manage the positioning and size of objects. - Move AND resize ;-) - Define a minimum or maximum width - Keep objects aligned to the right, left or centred - Apply complex constraints using formulas.
In this dialog, the objects in red show the behaviour of the properties managed by 4D, the others are managed by the class.
trans-unit.target:
You're familiar with the move and resize properties offered by the form editor for objects: Do nothing, move OR resize. Is that enough for you? Not for me. This dialog shows you how to use the "constraints" property of the "form" class to better manage the positioning and size of objects. - Move AND resize ;-) - Define a minimum or maximum width - Keep objects aligned to the right, left or centred - Apply complex constraints using formulas.
In this dialog, the objects in red show the behaviour of the properties managed by 4D, the others are managed by the class.

trans-unit.source:
No code here ðŸ˜± Everything is done with CSS.
Learn to adjust: - Title, style and text - Appearance and display - Default action - Input and text properties - and more
And all this from the "class" property of course, but also simply from the name of a widget, its associated action or another property
trans-unit.target:
No code here ðŸ˜± Everything is done with CSS.
Learn to adjust: - Title, style and text - Appearance and display - Default action - Input and text properties - and more
And all this from the "class" property of course, but also simply from the name of a widget, its associated action or another property

trans-unit.source: This dialog shows how to use the search widget. This is a sub-form which displays a search box with icons adapted to the platform and which recalls the host form when the user modifies their input. Some options allow you to adjust the behaviour. You can define : - The placeholder text (default: none) - The shortcut (and any associated modifier) to activate the search box (default: Ctrl/Cmd "f") - The tooltip displayed by the widget (default: "âŒ˜-f" on macOS & "âŒƒ-f" on Windows) - The input type, which will define the correct input filter (default: text). - The instant mode, in which user keystrokes are sent to the host form as they are entered, or all at once when the widget loses focus (default: True = instant).
trans-unit.target: This dialog shows how to use the search widget. This is a sub-form which displays a search box with icons adapted to the platform and which recalls the host form when the user modifies their input. Some options allow you to adjust the behaviour. You can define : - The placeholder text (default: none) - The shortcut (and any associated modifier) to activate the search box (default: Ctrl/Cmd "f") - The tooltip displayed by the widget (default: "âŒ˜-f" on macOS & "âŒƒ-f" on Windows) - The input type, which will define the correct input filter (default: text). - The instant mode, in which user keystrokes are sent to the host form as they are entered, or all at once when the widget loses focus (default: True = instant).
